column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/12/cleanup-needed/|Cleanup Needed|So lost in the ecstasy of the Bucs win against the Giants two weeks ago was the reality that the Bucs fumbled four times in that game. Last week’s win in Charlotte saw two more fumbles for the men in pewter and white. Thankfully
column2: the football gods were kind and the Bucs recovered nearly all those fumbles
column3: but it was/is a little concerning. However
column4: ball security can be coached up with improvement expected. Tonight
column5: Joe watched game film of the past two Bucs games and afterwards felt compelled to look up fumbling stats. Per NFL.com the Bucs lead the NFL in running game fumbles this season with 11
column6: after only 4 last year. Ouch! The Cowboys have the second-most with 9. The NFL team average is about 5 1/2 for this season. Obviously
column7: this is something the Bucs must correct before bouncing balls further short-circuit the season. (See Falcons-Bucs on Oct. 3). But the good news is there’s reason to expect the Bucs to be sharper with the football after two messy weeks
column8: especially at home with fewer distractions. If not
column9: fumbling issues are sure to catch up to the team
column10: and Anthony Nelson can’t be counted on for a bailout every week.|2024-12-07 22:10:00|203|3|4|The Bucs|Bucs struggling with fumbles but can improve with coaching.|2|Mixed opinions on fumbling issues and coaching errors
column12: ""post"": ""Good stuff Joe. Something not mentioned is once a guy gets any sniff of a reputation as a fumbler. It becomes the focus of an entire defense when he gets the ball. creating \u2026. even more fumbles.""
column30: ""post"": ""Lack of situational coaching contributed to Bucky\u2019s fumble against the Fowlclowns. He did not have both arms wrapped around the football
column31: and that is due to absence of detailed coaching and situational ignorance.  Lots to clean up all right.""

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/12/a-get-off-my-back-game-for-todd-bowles/|A Get-Off-My-Back Game For Todd Bowles|So back on Sept. 5
column2: Tampa Bay fans here were hit with a flash poll and asked the question
column3: ‘How many regular season wins for the Bucs this season?’ With about 90 minutes to respond on a Thursday morning
column5: ” the choice of 45.4 percent of the 735 respondents. Bucs fans were optimistic
column6: and rightfully so. The team finished the 2023 season on a high note
column7: the new playcaller was inspiring confidence
column8: free agency locked in Bucs stars
column9: the draft from the A-list general manager felt solid and the division didn’t look strong. Bring on a fourth consecutive NFC South crown! But here the Bucs are at 6-6. It’s a solid record considering their tough schedule and key injuries
column10: but it’s a painful record because of how the team lost to the Falcons twice — after knocking off the Lions and Eagles. If ever there was a rollercoaster season
column11: this has been it. And it started on Day 1 with fans expecting double-digit wins. Keep in mind a combined 38 percent of fans voting in the poll pegged the Bucs at 11
column12: 12 or 13-plus wins this season. Optimism was flowing and the Bucs life felt great. Today
column13: Joe sees the team and legions of Bucs fans at a crossroads. A majority are down on Todd Bowles
column14: but he’s got a chance Sunday to flip a ton of skeptics. Put this Bucs team at 7-6 and in great position to meet preseason expectations after a solid beating of the Raiders
column15: and Joe thinks a lot of daggers (not all) will stop being thrown Bowles’ way. The this year’s 4-6 record felt inexcusable based on how it evolved
column16: but getting to 7-6 would feel mighty acceptable
column17: almost like a rightful December reset for a team with a lot of weapons and a lot of holes. A “W” tomorrow would/should get a lot of fans off Bowles’ back. But an unthinkable home loss to a miserable Raiders team? Well
column18: that would be one heavy load for Bowles to shed in the coming weeks. Good luck

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/12/liam-coen-in-some-impressive-company/|Liam Coen In Impressive Company|Joe thinks it’s fair to suggest Andy Reid may be the best offensive coach in the NFL. Not long ago he had one of the most potent offenses in the game. After attrition
column3: Reid and his Chiefs are left with a world-class quarterback
column4: an aging star tight end and not much else

column6: per Rich Hribar of Sharp Football Analysis. That’s best in the league. This does not shock Joe one bit. Reid simply knows how to put offenses together and craft gameplans. He will be in the Pro Football Hall of Fame someday. Deservedly. Well
column7: guess who is No. 2 in the league in converting third downs? That would be Liam Coen and the Bucs. And yes
column8: it surprises Joe — even though their third-down success is mentioned on every broadcast and pregame show. The Bucs aren’t too far behind
column9: converting 48 percent of their third downs. Joe would suspect that’s a great look for Baker Mayfield
column10: as well. He’s the one on the field executing the Coen’s plays and audibling out of them when needed. And
column12: Mayfield has the third-most touchdown passes in the NFL (25)
column13: second-most 300-yard passing games (four) and second-most three-touchdown passing games (five). Not bad for the 18th-highest-paid quarterback. column7: ” NFL analyst and high school coach Tyler Brooke seems to believe he has a handle on offensive line stats. And one is very good for Wirfs. Tristan Wirfs is the only OT with less than 10 Pressures allowed this season (7) that has had 400+ pass blocking snaps 🛡️ A literal human shield. Brooke also notes that his information suggests Wirfs has yet to give up a sack this fall. Regardless
